description: Pharmacy First pathway for shingles assessment, including ophthalmic red flags and antiviral supply decisions.
inclusion: Adults aged 18 years and over with dermatomal vesicular rash consistent with shingles.
No features requiring urgent specialist referral.
exclusion: Ophthalmic involvement or Ramsay Hunt syndrome.
Pregnancy or breastfeeding without specialist advice.
Immunocompromise, severe pain, or widespread dissemination.
safetyNetting: Seek urgent care if eye involvement develops or rash spreads beyond one dermatome.
Return if new neurological symptoms appear or pain becomes severe.
Advise contacting GP if rash not crusted after 7 days of treatment.

questions.label: Renal impairment or contraindication to aciclovir

pass.label: Age within Pharmacy First shingles range.

result.headline: Refer - patient under 18
result.summary: Children with suspected shingles require GP/paediatric review.

fail.label: Dermatomal rash not confirmed - consider alternative diagnosis.

result.headline: Refer - differential diagnosis required
result.summary: If dermatomal pattern absent, arrange GP review for alternative causes.
actions: Arrange GP assessment for non-dermatomal rash.

warnings: Pregnancy/breastfeeding - discuss with GP prior to treatment.
Check renal function and consider dose adjustment or referral.

pass.label: Ophthalmic/cranial nerve involvement - urgent referral required.

result.headline: Urgent referral - ophthalmic or cranial nerve involvement
result.summary: Same-day specialist assessment required for eye/ear involvement.
actions: Arrange urgent ophthalmology/ENT review or direct to A&E.

result.headline: Refer - immunocompromise is an exclusion
result.summary: Requires GP/secondary care oversight due to complication risk.
actions: Arrange GP review and provide interim analgesia advice.

result.headline: Supply Aciclovir 800 mg five times daily for 7 days
result.summary: Presentation within 72 hours - antiviral treatment recommended.
actions: Supply Aciclovir 800 mg five times daily for 7 days with hydration advice.
Advise analgesia (NSAID/paracetamol) and avoid contact with vulnerable individuals.
Provide written safety-netting including escalation for eye involvement.

supply.dosage: Take one tablet five times daily for 7 days
supply.notes: Ensure adequate hydration and adjust dose in renal impairment.

pass.label: Presentation 72-120h with risk factors - consider delayed antiviral.

result.headline: Discuss delayed antiviral with GP
result.summary: Outside 72h window but risk factors present - liaise with GP for antiviral consideration.
actions: Contact GP to discuss antiviral prescription due to severe pain or new lesions.
Provide analgesia advice and skin care guidance.
Monitor closely and escalate if ocular symptoms develop.

result.headline: Self-care advice for late-presenting shingles
result.summary: Presentation beyond antiviral window without high-risk features - provide supportive care.
actions: Recommend analgesia (paracetamol/NSAID if suitable) and consider topical lidocaine patches for pain.
Advise keeping rash clean/dry and covering lesions.
Arrange follow-up if pain persists beyond 4 weeks or new symptoms develop.
safetyNet: Seek urgent care if vision changes, rash crosses midline, or new neurological symptoms occur.
Contact GP if lesions have not crusted within 7 days.
